Comments_List: 5 hours
around 2 hours
2-3 hours on weekly homeworkws
ABOUT FIVE HOURS
15 hours

5 hours
Over 12 hours.

I think the course concept was interesting. We tried to prove the OLS model for regression and talk about how it was maybe not always the best way to estimate. But because of the structure of the course you could get by without understanding the math or the implications. Then, we didn't do similar proofs for logistic regression. Additionally, the homeworks often had errors which made it very confusing and often much more difficult to complete correctly.
students need basic R knowledge beforehand

It was hard to follow sometimes that everything (including the theoretical stuff) was in R. It seemed easier to do slides for the stuff that was like "this is how a regression works" even just for facility of review in the aftermath.

Strength: learn regression and how to work R from base up; very useful for future use
weakness: not very organized, no clear class structure
The course is great.

This course is structured poorly. The instructor does't have basic idea how to develop the course.

The instructor posted the final project on around Dec. 15th but it is due on Dec. 19th.

Strengths: the textbook that the professor chose for this course is excellent - very clear, explains both the biostatistics and coding behind regression concepts, professor is kind and approachable

Weaknesses: class feels too unstructured, difficult to follow the concept that was being taught due to unstructured teaching and jumping back and forth between windows especially for someone with little experience in R

Suggestions: Use powerpoints when introducing concepts in class, a short background on the type of regression we are going over in class that day including assumptions, applications, etc would be very helpful
I definitely learned a lot but the class seemed kind of unorganized. It could be improved by having more concrete deadlines and clearer assignments.

Strengths - I learned R and got comfortable using R to run regressions.

Weaknesses - Lectures are very disorganized and move way too fast, especially for someone who is new to R. The assumptions on what students should already know in regards to R and statistical concepts are not properly conveyed. The constant switching back and forth between R and Terminal (or whatever it's called) was jarring and made it hard to type notes. Also PLEASE give a short break in the middle of class or better yet, make class shorter because almost everyone stopped paying attention an hour in to class.
Loved this class. At first it was hard and abstract because R is a complex platform to understand. But after 2-3 weeks, it became a breeze. I enjoyed learning R and how Dr. Kane structured the class.

This course was effective at introducing me to R programming. It should probably be re-advertised as a course in R rather than a focus on regression analysis. The statistics content was often taught somewhat disorganizedly, and unclearly. It could be improved by including more formal statistics instruction, and especially more information on assessing the goodness of models. Even the R content could be presented in a more straightforward way, with more instruction in fundamental practices/concepts in R programming. I think a lot of this could be facilitated by formally adopting the textbook and assigning accompanying readings. I would say the strength of course instruction was the in-class analyses performed, which was where I learned most. Probably the best part of the class or the midterm and final exams, which gave plenty of latitude for exploring questions and trying out techniques. I really enjoyed the exams.

I found this course very useful both in instruction on R as well as the concepts related to regression analysis. 

I think the course could have been structured in a more linear fashion, with more of an introduction to R syntax and basic features earlier on.

Also, I did now know that the course had TAs until midway through. I think that providing a larger role for TAs could have been useful.

Great course! This course taught us very important knowledge of regression modeling, and we learned lots of updated modeling methods, tools and resources. We also got a chance to participate data analysis communities.
Liked his style of using real time questions to learn material. There should be an intro R class first.
The material should be helpful, but is not well-organized and prepared.

I think he was just hard to follow as an instructor. He was very receptive to questions but sometimes got caught up in the code and it wasn't always clear what the takeaways at the end of each lecture were.

I think the course could be dramatically improved by having learning objectives listed explicitly at the beginning of each session.
strength: answers questions well, improvement: posting the lecture before class so we can follow along instead of trying to code along (gets confusing for people who are just learning to code)
He is being responsive to questions. But the lecture notes could be more organized.
The professor was enthusiastic about the course material bit sometimes things felt a little bit disorganized.
weakness: homework is not related with lecture.

Teaching needs to be more structured and clear (provide textbook chapters that follow with his lectures)
His lecture style is disorganized and often lead to confusion (maybe teach stat/math part away from R, and then demonstrate how things can be done in R)
Michael is nice but he is not responsive to emails.
I can't evaluate the instructor's strengths because he does't present it in the course.
Kind professor, could do with more structure in his teaching.

My only criticism is that sometimes Professor Kane's homework assignments were not very clear/had a lot of typos and mistakes. I never knew if the homework that was currently posted was the final one or if I should wait to get an updated version.

Kane clearly is incredibly knowledgeable about R and is willing to make sure students are exposed to all of the advantages of the software. He was extremely responsive to questions in class. In terms of teaching though, a little more organization would have been a bit better.

Fantastic professor. Very flexible and sensitive to student's feedbacks, needs. Goes the extra mile to help student's understand difficult concepts. Always willing to review concepts and to meet and discuss issues with codes. I enjoyed the flexibility of the class structure. I would prefer if lecture codes were posted prior to class so that I could focus more on the material than trying to copy the code. But otherwise, great great class!

Strength: fair grader

weakness: never prepare his lecture. Keeping debugging in the class . It is inefficient for us to take notes.

I really appreciate Prof. Kane's willingness to live program R coding class, as it helps demonstrate problem-solving and adaptation. At the same time, sometimes the class got sidetracked by very specific programming questions, and while Prof. Kane was able to answer them, that often led to very long tangents (30+ min) that were not relevant to most people in the class. I would recommend finding some balance between being willing to answer very specific questions, and keeping in mind the relevance of questions to the entire class.

I am impressed at the instructor's ability to teach both in tandem and in a way that was constantly engaging and sensitive to student needs. I really appreciated the instructor's commitment to incorporating student feedback into the course design at all times and found office hours with the instructor to be very useful for resolving ambiguities or any lack of understanding on my part.

The only think I think the professor could do to improve the class is to make sure we are provided the code used in class as soon as possible, preferably before class, but immediately afterwards in those cases where new coding is developed in class (which was a fun and engaging way of presenting material).

Professor Kane is great! He is very patient with us. He is good at explaining concepts in a way we could understand. He taught us on how to work on projects and solving problems step by step, and he kept updating all codes on Canvas.
my advice is that professor Michael should organize the course more clearly.
Great. Very nice.
The instructor is very nice, but it is hard to catch up that he want us to know in lecture. The material is not well-organized.
I think you could get deeper stats knowledge from a course in the S&DS department or Justin Thomas's course at SOM.
Waive it.
Class content will be useful later on, but class structure wise needs more work by the instructor
The course is great.
Strongly don't recommend this course.

This class would be good for a student who already has a good understanding of regression/biostatistics and R and is looking for a class to enhance those skills, rather than for a student who is looking to learn these skills from scratch.
You learn linear, logistic, binomial, and polynomial regression in R. It's not very exciting but will definitely be useful if that's something you're going to use when writing your thesis.
The class was good in that I was forced to learn R but I basically had to teach it to myself, which was frustrating.

If you want to learn R, then this is the class to take. I suggest taking intro to categorical data analysis or another bio stats intro course first. But for an excellent learning experience in R coding, this is the class to take.

This is a reasonable class to try to learn R, but does not cover much formal instruction on regression analysis or statistical topics. It can be somewhat disorganized. The exams are a lot of fun because you can pretty much do whatever you want!

This is an excellent course to take after basic biostatistics, especially if you are interested in learning R. I would recommend this course to anyone who plans to do regression analysis in their future work (or is doing so now).
Strongly recommend it to everybody!
I dont suggest students take this course.
